qas.question: Who retained indigenous language and culture after the Spanish conquest?
What did the highland peasants resist attempts at?
What re-emerged during the Katarista movement in the 1970s?
What march successfully pressured the national government to sign the ILO Convetion 169?

context: Large numbers of <a0_0>Bolivian highland peasants<a0_0/> retained indigenous language, culture, customs, and communal organization throughout the Spanish conquest and the post-independence period. They mobilized to resist various attempts at the <a1_0>dissolution of communal landholdings<a1_0/> and used legal recognition of "empowered caciques" to further communal organization. <a2_0>Indigenous revolts<a2_0/> took place frequently until 1953. While the National Revolutionary Movement government begun in 1952 discouraged self-identification as indigenous (reclassifying rural people as campesinos, or peasants), renewed <a3_0>ethnic and class militancy<a3_0/> re-emerged in the Katarista movement beginning in the 1970s. Lowland indigenous peoples, mostly in the east, entered national politics through the 1990 <a4_0>March for Territory and Dignity<a4_0/> organized by the CIDOB confederation. That march successfully pressured the national government to sign the ILO Convention 169 and to begin the still-ongoing process of recognizing and titling indigenous territories. The 1994 Law of Popular Participation granted "grassroots territorial organizations" that are recognized by the state certain rights to govern local areas.
